title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Two miles from St. Boswells is the village of Maxtou, and, on the opposite side of the river, in a delightful situation, is Mertoun House, the seat of Lord Polwarth.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: On the Green is held the fair of St. Boswells, the principal market for sheep and lambs in the south of Scotland.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The old village of St. Boswells appears to have stood in the vicinity of the Church, where the foundations of houses are occasionally discovered in the operations of agriculture.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: (2|) Newtown St. Boswells, village and railway station.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The most direct way to Dryburgh Abbey is either by road or railway to Newtown St. Boswells, from which the road turns directly to the left.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: " It says the stone is on the road to St. Boswells.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: Not far from Newtown St. Boswells, we came upon some children in charge of two nurses and a governess.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: The road to St. Boswells was easily found; but though we scrutinized both sides of it with careful eyes, we could see no sign of either stone or burn.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: " It's on the road to St. Boswells.

title: Rambles with an American,
author: [Jacques, Edward Tyrell]
snippet: The wise pedestrian will strike off the main road at the beginning of Newtown St. Boswells and make his way to the back of the Dryburgh Hotel, and along the very Scottish village street that leads to the burn.
